G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and, as applicable to custody determinations concerning minor children, G.L. c. 209C, § 20), the Probate and Family Court has the authority to modify judgments relative to custody and parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require,” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and, as applicable to custody determinations concerning minor children, G.L. c. 209C, § 20), the Probate and Family Court has the authority to modify judgments relative to custody and parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require,” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, because this Court issued the original custody and parenting time judgment and the child resides within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard is paramount in determining custody and parenting time arrangements.

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that to modify an existing custody or parenting time order, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the two-part standard for modifying a prior custody judgment in Massachusetts: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances, and the modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests. Although the case focuses primarily on child support and SSDI credits, the court expressly recites and applies this standard to the custody modification issue, thereby supporting the proposition about Massachusetts courts’ consistent requirement for both elements.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that to modify an existing custody or parenting time order, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an initial custody determination and standards for considering domestic violence in custody awards, not the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting time order. The court does not articulate or apply a two-part test requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment and (2) best interests of the child for modification. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31; see also Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (the child’s stability, welfare, and development must be central in the Court’s analysis).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses how G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a)’s best-interests standard should be applied in custody determinations and emphasizes that a child’s welfare, needs, and stability are paramount. The court explains that stability and continuity, and preservation of satisfactory existing arrangements, are core to assessing the child’s best interests, and it repeatedly frames the custody analysis around the child’s welfare rather than parental claims. This directly supports the proposition that the child’s stability, welfare, and development must be central in the court’s analysis under the governing custody statutes (analogous in function to G.L. c. 208, § 31).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt:
“If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

“Ultimately, the judge concluded that the mother was more ‘attuned to [Kali’s] medical, educational, and daily needs’ and this tipped the balance as to where the best interests of the child lay.”

Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 454\u.proposition: A significant relocation or change in the living circumstances of a parent may constitute a material change warranting modification when it meaningfully affects the child’s schedule, stability, or welfare.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 454\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a removal/relocation may be allowed notwithstanding a surviving separation agreement, and what legal standard ("real advantage" under G.L. c. 208, § 30 vs. "countervailing equities") applies. It does not treat relocation or changed living circumstances as a "material change" standard for modification; in fact, it explicitly rejects using the ordinary modification standard in favor of the statutory removal standard. The case focuses on best interests/real advantage analysis for relocation, not on material-change doctrine or its threshold.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 454\u.relevant_excerpt: We must decide what standard the judge should apply to determine whether to grant a request for the removal of children from the Commonwealth: the c. 208, § 30, “real advantage” standard, the “countervailing equities” standard, or some other standard. The statute is controlling over the provision contracted by the parties. Therefore, the statutory standard is to be used, even in this case, where the parties have contracted for consent of the other before removal. The judge did not err in applying the statutory standard below.

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–52 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: A significant relocation or change in the living circumstances of a parent may constitute a material change warranting modification when it meaningfully affects the child’s schedule, stability, or welfare.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support decision, not a modification-of-custody decision based on relocation as a material change. It applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework for an initial removal request by the primary physical custodian, not the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting schedule due to a subsequent significant relocation or change in living circumstances. The court does not discuss ‘material change of circumstances’ in the context of custody or parenting-time modification triggered by relocation affecting the child’s schedule or stability, so it does not provide authority for the stated proposition.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’… Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Courts have broad discretion to modify parenting time to reduce excessive travel and disruption to the child’s routine when such arrangements are no longer consistent with the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation generally under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and affirms the trial judge’s reduction of the father’s visitation, but it does not mention travel burdens, excessive travel, or disruption to the child’s routine as a basis for modifying parenting time. The reduction in visitation is justified by parental conflict and concerns about the children’s welfare, not by travel or logistical disruption. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about reducing excessive travel and routine disruption.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 246–47 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Courts have broad discretion to modify parenting time to reduce excessive travel and disruption to the child’s routine when such arrangements are no longer consistent with the child’s best interests.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, a one‑year suspension of visitation, and removal, but it does not address modifying parenting time specifically to reduce excessive travel or disruption to a child’s routine. The removal analysis focuses on the ‘real advantage’ test and best interests in the context of relocation, not on adjusting parenting schedules due to travel burdens. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about courts’ discretion to modify parenting time to reduce travel and disruption.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Ultimately, the judge must determine that removal is in the best interests of the child… In the present case, the judge did make findings of fact that are relevant to a proper determination whether removal would be a real advantage to the mother… However, the order entered by the judge does not satisfy the requirements of § 30. The statute requires a judicial determination that removal will be a real advantage and ultimately in the child’s best interests.”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.proposition: The child’s educational needs and ability to get adequate rest are important aspects of the “best interests” inquiry.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Blixt discusses constitutional standards for grandparent visitation, the presumption in favor of parental decision-making, and the need to show significant harm to the child. It does not specifically address the child’s educational needs or need for rest, nor does it identify those factors as components of the best-interests analysis. The case focuses on parental rights and harm to the child generally, so it does not provide direct authority for the proposition as stated.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.relevant_excerpt: More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare. The requirement of significant harm presupposes proof of a showing of a significant preexisting relationship between the grandparent and the child. In the absence of such a relationship, the grandparent must prove that visitation between grandparent and child is nevertheless necessary to protect the child from significant harm.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868–69 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Where a schedule that was once appropriate becomes detrimental due to changes in circumstances, the Court is not bound to preserve the existing arrangement; rather, it must fashion a parenting plan that reflects the current realities and the child’s welfare.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision focusing on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test and best interests analysis, not on modification of parenting schedules that have become detrimental due to changed circumstances. While the opinion discusses that a custodial arrangement can be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances (here, remarriage), it does not say that a court is ‘not bound’ to preserve an existing parenting schedule or that it must refashion a parenting plan to reflect current realities; rather, it remands for reconsideration of the relocation request under the correct legal framework. Thus, it does not squarely support the proposition as stated.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Court’s power to modify custody and parenting time is ongoing and is exercised to respond flexibly to the evolving needs of the child and the circumstances of the parents.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for an initial custody award and for permitting removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30; it does not discuss the court’s ongoing or continuing power to modify custody or parenting time orders over time. Nor does it reference flexible, post-judgment modification in response to evolving needs of the child or changing parental circumstances. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about continuing modification power.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
